job_title: Coder in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Benefits Good pay Good environment
cons: No cons so far, not much growth

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in New York, NY
pros: Only pros are the mission of service to LGBTQ+ patients
cons: Where to start? I worked here for years as a provider and was treated horribly by my supervisor-basically every issue was met with “oh that sounds really hard” with no changes made. No raises other than union cost of living raise which is usually 2-3%. If you are anything other than positive at all times and have legitimate complaints about how the practice is run-you get spoken to you about your attitude, particularly if you are female identified. 15 minute visits for all patients (including physicals and new patients). Very complicated patients with zero back up from management. No help with filling out forms. I’ve literally had to call other doctors offices for record because medical records says “that isn’t our job.” Patients have lunged at me and threatened me and management has done nothing. All of the providers here are very unhappy leaving in droves. Women identified providers are treated much worse than cis male counterparts. Everyone will be very nice in the hiring process and once you are in all of your concerns will be dismissed.

job_title: Lead Patient Care Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Getting to work with a marginalized community. Lots of room for growth if you seek it Immediate Supervisors listen to you
cons: Upper management is stagnant Constantly dealing with traumatized patients Communication break downs not being addressed

review_title: Ok job, they will screw you over

job_title: Patient Care Associate (PCA) in New York, NY

cons: The pay is mediocre. The management is clique-y and everything operates on favoritism. A lot of people are two-faced and very toxic. It's classic corporate culture with a happy inclusive LGBTQ+ façade.

job_title: Medical Provider in New York, NY

job_title: Clinical Manager in Chelsea, NY
pros: I was able to expand my clinical expertise and work with wonderful therapists and psychiatrist.
cons:
I was promised a  promotion and, then a year later, I was told that I would be promoted with 4 other employees who had zero management experience and that my role. 

I was lied to  including being told taking a lesser title would be helpful for a raise in the future (a year before I was told the job I was promised didn't exist).

This caused significant trauma for me as I had been lied to in private meetings over 2.5 years and needed significant treatment after I left. I had strong relationships at work  and was shocked that no one had my back.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits including 100% free healthcare (no copays, deductibles, etc). Vision is limited at ~$130/yr. I've always had plenty of PTO, new hires start at 22 days.  Short term disability (60% of salary)- no specific paid parental leave. Tuition assistance was recently added at about $3,000/yr. Depending on the department you work in, you will have very different experiences. Some managers are great, most are debatable.
cons: My largest frustrations have come from seemingly incompetent/lazy management. Some people are clearly here just to collect a check and look good. HR policies are vague and open to bias.

review_title: An essential and progressive institution, but personal sacrifices required to serve the mission.
job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: You get to be a member of one of the leading (if not THE leading) forces of advocacy for and practitioners of LGBTQ+ health.  The patients and staff form an amazing, unique community, welcoming at every turn. You will learn a great deal, no matter what role you play. The benefits package is expensive, but very good/comprehensive. There's a great sense of teamwork and solidarity, and you won't have a similar work experience anywhere. The validation I feel working for this institution is both personal and professional, and there's no doubt Callen-Lorde fills a role unmet anywhere else in the community on multiple levels--transcare, HIV+ care, mental health services, etc.
cons: Senior management can be extraordinarily out of touch with employee concerns, and a great deal is done to justify keeping the doors open at this (undeniably indispensible) nonprofit--requiring more work for no compensation, seeing an incredible amount of patients in an unreasonably short time, etc. Billing services is inconsistent and uncooperative. The wages for employees aren't competitive, particularly for bottom-rung administrative staff. There's very little room for career advancement, too, so there's a huge amount of employee turnover. Disruptive patients are kowtowed to instead of discharged, which leaves frontline staff such as nurses and admins open to being verbally abused and harassed instead of being able to focus on the majority of wonderful clients at the institution. Feedback about systems issues can fall on deaf ears, and much-needed policy overhauls can take months upon months, because of the glut of managers who must come to an agreement. The facility is wildly overcrowded, and the HVAC system has been an issue for years, to the extent temperatures during extreme weather have been intolerable. The agency can also occasionally fall into thinking it is free of problematic political issues, which leaves the most vulnerable staff and clients (largely trans*) open to uncomfortable/threatening encounters without much management backup. Focus recently has felt more bottom-line oriented than community oriented, and it feels like there is a danger of CL losing its community-focused identity.

review_title: Excellent front-line staff, lovely family, poor management and serious disrespect towards staff.
job_title: Patient Navigator in New York, NY
pros: The staff are excellent. Front-line staff are highly dedicated and empathetic. The staff are so close knit that it genuinely can become a family setting. I developed so many tight relationships there. Many of the staff are very LGBTQ competent and the HIV care there is excellent. Care coordination staff are tremendous individuals, nursing staff rock, mental health is a fun bunch of people, front desk staff are the hardest workers. The staff events are fun. People are low key and generally relaxed. Its also now a union job so the benefits, pay, and job protection will become much better as the staff negotiate a contract. You can do amazing work for your patients and can be a fierce advocate for the community. Work pace in many positions is flexible as are hours. Vacation time is good so far.
cons: Way low pay, disrespectfully so. The tight-knit nature can become a source for bad boundaries, gossip, cliques, and exclusivity in promotions. Several managers are highly disrespectful and thus the turnaround rate is high. Hopefully the new staff union will help prevent turnaround. Promotions are limited, infrequent, and with low raises. Many men do very well at Callen-Lorde while women and trans folks get passed over and are given sexist reviews. HR doesn't filter out transphobic and homophobic staff super well. Its not super often but its not uncommon for them to hire folks who mispronoun and say sexist stuff. Management does not value its staff and fails to tap into the potential of the staff. I often felt like I was stuck in a game with my boss to try and get noticed and promoted, its a game that is not worth playing. You won't win. The agency only ever helped me realize their goals rather than my own.  The health insurance is not very good, copays are high, premiums are high. I couldn't access my own healthcare, my patients had better care than I did as a staff member.

review_title: Amazing place to work, competent staff, and patient first addittudes!
job_title: HIV Patient Navigator in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment... Meeting the need.
cons: Should be bigger space and Executive management really over-practices hyerarcle management style.  Very old and inefficient model in such a progressive service.

job_title: Lead Patient Navigator in New York, NY
pros: Working along side the LGBTQ community, flexibility with scheduling, excellent healthcare benefits, unionized
cons: My biggest con with Callen-Lorde was there was very little room for growth. I asked my supervisors for opportunities or projects several times, but they would never respond to my request. Managers in the Care Coordination Department are a joke. Despite attending trainings like "Diversity and Inclusion" and "How to foster growth on your team," they do very little to boost their staff up. Most of the time, staff end of feeling demoralized and burned out when interacting with management. Most entry level staff are people of color, and there is a very stark difference in how white individuals and people of color are treated. Most managers are white, and they very much pretend to care about reducing racial oppression. When it comes to actually redistributing power in the working relationship in order to create a healthier dynamic, they refuse to institute practices that would foster that type of relationship. Most managers react to disagreement through very punitive means, like writing staff up for insubordination instead of changing problematic practices that hurt staff and lead to staff acting out. Additionally, I have seen managers cover for other managers who have sexually harassed other employees in the workplace. When I tried to address my own relationship with the same employee to a senior manager, she shut the conversation down. It felt like she was more interested in protecting the person who had sexually harassed a number of people on the team instead of asking how I was affected by working alongside with a problematic person for several years. I was very disappointed to see how unsupported I was in the moment.

review_title: Fulfilling at times; repetitive often; constantly in flux
job_title: Medical Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Working at Callen-Lorde was a wild ride. I worked in the youth services department known as HOTT where I worked with committed and knowledgeable staff. The patients were for the most part a pleasure to serve. You often got to see faces light up at the affirming environment and shelter that HOTT provided. You got to see youth and young adults from the beginning of their transition and transform into their more authentic selves. (Primarily we served transgender and gender non-conforming youth when it came to case management activities) Staff had the opportunity to travel. Atlanta and the Philly Trans Health Conference were 2 of the destinations. Work/life balance I would rate as good. You were not over-worked, had the ability to schedule many of your case-loaded patients and could devote considerable time to them, something many providers in Callen-Lorde could not do. (The adult program case managers had more hectic schedules.)  
Other pros:
There were some good and supportive people in HR. I was thankful for that.
The staff in general. A pleasure to work alongside special, fun and caring people.
Internal promotions were very common; staff development evident
Working to change the culture and appoint people of color in senior and director position. An independent group was hired. 
The union 1199 is now active at Callen-Lorde
cons:
The culture in my department transformed quickly during my tenure. What did not change was the territorial nature. I was met with suspicion by some staff members, it was a "prove yourself" vibe. While at first it was a less intense environment, senior management became more involved to increase productivity and remove the autonomy of the HOTT program and re-organize the case management department under the umbrella of the "adult program." Your work became strongly scrutinized, especially the amount of encounters. Middle management was expanded and a direct supervisor hired to  manage the case managers.  HOTT program management monitored your schedule and work, often met with a director to scrutinize activities. Punitive actions (write-ups) were more common.  Case management was not well respected amongst some of the team members, a hierarchy was clear. Case management disproportionally faced constant change. Feedback was often interpreted as combative; it became difficult to work in an environment so focused on productivity. The number of our face to face encounters was prominently displayed each month during our weekly all staff, treatment team meetings. I came to dread those weekly meetings. 
Other cons:
Not everyone in upper management is committed to the mission. 
Medical staff received wine and fancy baked goods during the holidays while most of the other staff got candy and chocolates. (That really rankled me!)
There are stooges who will report back Facebook posts to HR. Be careful who you trust and friend.

review_title: Great benefits, decent pay but no growth potential
job_title: Prevention Outreach Provider in New York, NY
pros: Excellent benefits including zero out of pocket costs for insurance premiums, deductibles or copays. Commuter benefits, tuition reimbursement, generous PTO.

A lot of hesitancy to fire existing problematic employees. Okay place if you're looking for an organization that will accept the bare minimum and be complacent. Would not recommend if you're looking to get promoted.
